revision.text:
{{Polish Underground State sidebar}} [[File:POL województwo zachodniopomorskie COA.svg|thumb|right|200px|The Griffin, traditional symbol of [[Pomerania]], after which the organization was named]]
The '''Pomeranian Griffin''' secret military organization ({{lang-pl|Tajna Organizacja Wojskowa Gryf Pomorski}}) was a [[Polish resistance movement in World War II|Polish anti-Nazi resistance group]] active in [[Pomerania]] and [[East Prussia]] during [[World War II]]. A major Polish resistance organization in the Pomerania region, at its height in 1943 it might have had as many as 20,000 members, although only about 500 were active partisans in the forests ([[leśni]]).<ref name=bib>{{pl icon}} Piotr Szubarczyk, [http://www.bibula.com/?p=19434 Z historii TOW “Gryf Pomorski”], Bibuła: Pismo Niezależne, 2010-03-15</ref><ref name=sitwp/>
The name of the organization referred to the traditional [[coat of arms]] of Pomerania, which consists of either the black (for [[Gdansk Pomerania]]) or the red (for [[House of Pomerania|Western Pomerania]]) [[griffin]].
==Formation==
After the [[German invasion of Poland]], [[Pomeranian Voivodeship (1919–1939)|Polish Pomeranian territories]] were annexed into the German ([[Reichsgau Danzig-West Prussia]]).<ref name=bib/> As elsewhere in Poland, resistance organizations soon appeared.<ref name=sitwp>{{pl icon}} [http://sitwp.umwp.pl/gryf_pomorski/historia.htm Historia], Tajna Organizacja Wojskowa GRYF POMORSKI, on the pages of the Urząd Marszałkowski Województwa Pomorskiego</ref> The Pomeranian Griffin organization was created on July 7, 1941 in [[Czarna Dąbrowa]]<ref>http://forum.danzig.de/showthread.php?11624-Interview-Gerhard-Jeske-1980-In-der-Kachubei-versteckt</ref> near [[Bytów]], out of three smaller predecessor organizations: the ''[[Kashubian Griffin]]'' secret military organization (''Tajna Organizacjia Wojskowa "Gryf Kaszubski"''), the [[Military Organization for Independence]] (''Wojskowa Organizacja Niepodległościowa''), and a partisan unit codenamed ''"Zawisza"'' (after [[Zawisza the Black]]).<ref name=sitwp/> According to Polish historian [[Tomasz Strzembosz]], the groundwork for the organization might have been laid down before the war by Colonel [[Ludwik Muzyczki]].<ref name=bib/>
==Operations==
The organization's charter stressed its [[Catholic]] nature<ref name=bib/><ref name=sitwp/> and declared its purpose as self-defense,<ref name=bib/> aid to the Polish population of Pomerania in the face of [[Nazi crimes against ethnic Poles|German terror]], and preparation for an eventual uprising against Nazi Germany.<ref name=sitwp/> In addition to sabotage operations carried out by its forest partisan units, the organization was active in spreading [[anti-Nazi]] [[propaganda]] and in intelligence activities (notably, the Pomeranian Griffin was involved in [[Home Army and V-1 and V-2|the intelligence gathering on the V-1 and V-2 rockets]]).<ref name=bib/><ref name=sitwp/>
The organization declared itself subordinate to the [[Polish Government in Exile]] in [[London]], and cooperated with the military structures of the [[Polish Underground State]] ([[Armia Krajowa]], the "Home Army") but stressed its regional autonomy.<ref name=bib/><ref name=sitwp/> In 1943 internal ideological conflicts escalated during negotiations over the subordination of the organization to the main Polish anti-Nazi resistance movement, the Home Army.<ref name=bib/> Polish resistance structures in Pomerania had suffered more than their fair share<!--what would have been a "fair share"--> of arrests, and Griffin leaders were wary of opening themselves up to a larger structure.<ref name=bib/> Furthermore, whereas the Home Army and the government in exile were run by a coalition of several parties, Griffin, while officially apolitical,<ref name=sitwp/> was mostly influenced by the [[endecja|National Democrats]].<ref name=bib/> A portion of the Griffin split to join the [[Miecz i Plug]] (''Sword and Plow'') nationalist movement.<ref name=bib/> However, Miecz i Plug had been infiltrated by the [[Gestapo]] or, according to other sources, by [[NKVD]] agents who first framed existing leaders for collaboration and then proceeded to establish real contacts with the Gestapo. <ref name="ipn dod">{{cite journal | url=http://archive.is/20121129194430/http://www.ipn.gov.pl/download/1/26791/IPN_55a.pdf | title=Śmierć jest zapłatą za zdradę. Historia organizacji "Miecz i Pług" | author=Sierchuła, Rafał | journal=Niezależna Gazeta Polska. Dodatek Specjalny IPN |date=September 2010 | pages=6}}</ref><ref name="spywars">{{cite book | title=Spy Wars: Moles, Mysteries, and Deadly Games | publisher=Yale University Press | author=Bagley, Tennent | year=2007 | pages=120 | isbn=9780300121988 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ng7myCguewAC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=Miecz+i+Plug++Gestapo&source=bl&ots=LG5-nik2HT&sig=8UKdSN43SFJeWNrCskSkPUpzoRY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8LrHT7O-OOfU2AXN093xCg&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=Miecz%20i%20Plug%20%20Gestapo&f=false}}</ref> Either way, as a result, many of the conspirators of the Griffin were compromised, arrested by the Nazis, and sent to [[Nazi concentration camps]].{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
[[Image:Ptasia Wola.jpg|thumb|left|250px|A modern reconstruction of a Pomeranian Griffin forest bunker]]
The remnants of the group survived until 1945, when the final order of its last commander instructed the soldiers to participate in the disarming of local German police forces and to provide logistic aid to the approaching [[Red Army]]. However, once Pomerania came under Soviet control, members of the group were persecuted and arrested by the Soviet authorities because of the organization's pro-Catholic and nationalistic character.<ref name=bib/> Many of the group's members who were arrested during this time ended up being sent to the [[gulag]] by the Soviets, alongside the same German soldiers and [[Gestapo]] agents against whom they fought during the war; others were executed.<ref name=bib/> Some historians argue that Griffin soldiers were treated much more harshly than even the [[Armia Krajowa]] and the [[cursed soldiers]] members.<ref name=bib/> In arresting the group's members the Soviet authorities often relied on information provided by former Gestapo agents who had infiltrated the group during the war and who had switched sides once Soviet victory was imminent.<ref name=bib/>
==Members== Two of the Pomeranian Griffin's most notable members were Lieutenant [[Józef Dambek]], Griffin's leader, and Colonel-Chaplain [[Józef Wrycza]], a widely respected Roman Catholic priest.<ref name=bib/><ref name=sitwp/> After Lieutenant Dambek was killed by the Germans in 1944, he was succeeded by Lieutenant [[Augustyn Westphal]].<ref name=bib/>
==Further reading== * Krzysztof Komorowski, ''Konspiracja pomorska 1939-1947'', Gdańsk 1993 * Gerald Stone, ''Slav outposts in Central European history : the Wends, Sorbs and Kashubs'', London, UK : Bloomsbury Academic, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing Plc, 2016 * Stanisław Salmonowicz and Jan Sziling (eds.), ''Pomorskie organizacje konspiracyjne (poza AK) 1939-1945'', Toruń 1994, * Mirosław Golon, ''Tajna Organizacja Wojskowa Gryf Pomorski wobec Armii Czerwonej a powojenne losy gryfowców'', Gdańsk 2000, * Józef Borzyszkowski (ed.), ''Losy Tajnej Organizacji Wojskowej Gryf Pomorski'', Gdańsk 2000, * Franciszek Szczęsny, ''Gryfowy szaniec'', Gdańsk 2003
